poem:
Azerbaijan at Dawn  

A gasp of earth—  
quivers beneath the Caspian,  
petals of fuel unfurling.  
In the shadowed rooms,  
teacups clink,  
chatter of promises—  
clouds of exhaust.  
Who can hear the roots  
tangled in pipelines,  
whisper the oil-drenched earth  
to pause,  
rest on silenced clay,  
before dawn flickers  
in flames anew?
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Cop29 host Azerbaijan set for major fossil gas expansion, report says Azerbaijan, the host of the Cop29 global climate summit, will see a large expansion of fossil gas production in the next decade, a new report has revealed. The authors said that the crucial negotiations should not be overseen by “those with a vested interest in keeping the world hooked on fossil fuels”. Azerbaijan’s state-owned oil and gas company, Socar, and its partners are set". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
